headline: Foolproof Rib Roast
description: Follow this simple rib roast recipe for a tender, succulent, standing rib roast that will definitely be the centerpiece of your holiday table!

video.name: How to Make Foolproof Rib Roast

name: Foolproof Rib Roast
recipeIngredient: 1 (5 pound) beef standing rib roast, at room-temperature (let sit out for 1 hour before starting recipe)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Place a rack in a roasting pan.
Combine salt, pepper, and garlic powder in a small cup.
Place room-temperature roast on the rack in the roasting pan with the fatty side up and the rib side on the bottom. Rub the seasoning onto the roast.
Roast for 1 hour in the preheated oven. Turn the oven off and leave the roast inside for 3 hours, without opening the door.
Turn the oven back on to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) and reheat the roast for 30 to 40 minutes. The internal temperature should be at least 145 degrees F (62 degrees C).
Remove from the oven and let rest for 10 minutes before carving.

review.reviewBody: Absolutely delicious. I added 1.5 tsp of rosemary to the rub and let it dry-age in the fridge for a couple days, it comes out fantastic every time.
Turning the oven off after 1 hour and leave the roast in for three hours , did not work well for me ; so I sliced it and stuck it back in the oven for an hour or so NOT ON THE RACK

My roast weighed 5.13 LBS. I followed the recipe exactly,except I didn't use garlic. I only used kosher salt (white not clear) and cracked pepper. I made it with sauted mushrooms and made au jus out of pan drippings by deglazzing the roasting pan. this was the 1st time I have made rib roast I am impressed with this recipe , follow 5 lb guideline and the recipe you won't be disappointed. The best roast ever. Thank you, SALSIEPIE for sharing.

I've made this 3 or 4 times now and it's turned out pretty much perfect each time. I was very scared to try it the first time, didn't want to ruin $60 worth of rib roast but the recipe worked great. I use the same 'rub' that I use on steak, this is how I do it, first rub the meat with a mixture of avocado oil and Kitchen Bouquet, then dust with garlic and onion powder and celery salt, and finally pat on Montreal Steak mixture. Makes an awesome crust, yum!

Like many others, my husband and I were a little hesitant to try this recipe; but it did turn out quite nicely! The simple rub is a big plus - nothing to detract from the fine taste of an expensive cut of beef. As others have mentioned, the size of the roast makes a BIG difference! If your roast is not around 5 pounds you will need to make adjustments in timing. It would be really helpful if this recipe addressed that issue.
Straight forward and easy to put together..

Followed another recommendation for a 5 pound roast and turned out great! 375 for 1 hour, oven turned down to 200(my oven doesn't hold heat well) for 2 hours, then 375 for 30 minutes! It was a bit on the rare side, but that's how we like it!

I make this every year at Easter & Christmas, with a full prime rib (18-19 lbs). Once the initial hour is up, I leave it there until about an hour before we want to eat, then turn the oven on 375. Once the oven reaches 375, start timing. For medium rare cook 20 minutes, if you like it more on the rare side 12-15 minutes, well done 35 minutes, then take out and let set 20 minutes. We like medium rare so I take it out when meat thermometer shows 115-118, but I have also just used the timing method when a thermometer was not available at a VBRO and it was still perfect!
This was awesome. I don’t consider myself a good cook. This made me look like one. Thank you

First time using this recipe. Cooked a 11.5 roast. It came out perfect. Took it out of the refrigerator 4.5 hours before the start of the cooking. Followed the recipe and it came out perfect! Will use this recipe again.

I have been using this recipe for Prime Rib for the last 16 years. I have only 1 suggestion. Put a long piece of duct tape across the front of the oven and either write on the tape or hang a sign or BOTH !! DO NOT OPEN OVEN ! One thing that will truly mess up the cooking method is the "peekers" Henny H. Edisto Island SC
I have made this over and over and every time, it’s a show stopper ! Super easy and full proof
works every time thank you sooo much

I had a 5lb. In oven at 375 for1 hour, turned oven off and kept in only 2 hrs (per comments, only has to sit in off oven for as little as an hour), then oven back on at 375 for 30 min.(NO MORE) Came out MED/RARE Everyone LOVED it!

When my friends came over for dinner I told them I was cooking the Rib Roast all day----I think they thought "OH NO !!!". Anyway---it was a hit !!! Perfect !!! Very easy. I highly recommend this recipe.
I have used this recipe every year for many years. Perfect every time.
Ive used this recipe for a 5lb since Christmas 2009. Works perfectly every year.

I use this recipe every time I cook my rib roasts. I generally cook 8-12 pound roasts. A few tips as I have used many different recipes and have used this method at least 12 times. First a big roast needs to be out of the refrigerator 3-4 hours before cook time. Second ( this is the most important note to remember) After preheating the oven and cooking at 375 for the hour and shutting it off, the temperature climb’s for at least three hours. You must I repeat YOU MUST pay attention to when the temperature stop’s climbing to the point of going down one degree, at that moment you must turn it back on to finish cooking. If you don’t your internal temperature will not be accurate and you will end up with a well done rib roast that’s only good for stew or soup. I learned this the hard way. You can also cook baked potatoes while preheating and sitting as long as they are on the sides of the oven and not directly under the roasting pan. Enjoy and wow your family and friends.
OMG. Followed the instructions to the letter, and it turned out perfect. Pink, but not red, center, juicy, tender. This recipe is magic!

I made it and you could've cut it with the side of your fork! Fabulous doesn't tell it all. One thing I did differently is I did not reheat the meat at the end of the closed oven period. Instead, we heated some aus ju for dipping. We served it with a side of asparagus for our meal. Wow.

We follow directions exactly. Our roast was 6 pounds. It was way too rare in the middle for our liking. Still quite a bit of blood. We put it back in the oven for another half an hour and it was fine. Tender and tasty
Delicious and PERFECTLY cook Rib Roast! I will never make a roast another way.

That said, I roasted exactly as directed, and after the total time called for (1 hr + 3hrs + 40mins) and the probe thermometer showed 120 degrees. I took it out as it smelled done. Rested it, and carved, and was done to a med rare as we prefer. My suggestion would be that if you roast to 145, you'll have a med well to well done after roasting.

I've made this about once a year for a while but ended up making a few changes. Instead of turning my oven off, I drop it to its lowest setting and start checking the temperature every 30 minutes, starting after 1 1/2 hours.

Early on, I ended up with roasts that were VERY rare to medium-well. Keeping the oven on lets me check it, but replaces the heat lost from opening the door. Plus, even though ovens are supposed to keep the heat in them, not every oven is made the same so they won't hold temperatures the same. Keeping it on low seems to take that part of the process out of the equation.

Fabulous! Used a 7 lb roast and followed this precisely - one hour on, 3 hours off, 30 min on and it was perfect! Medium rare. I did not open the oven door at any time. Wish I had thought to take a pic but it was a beautifully cooked roast, crispy on the outside (I used the rub mix recommended) and gorgeous reddish/pink throughout. Best recipe I’ve ever used.

Next time for this size roast (2 ribs) I would cut the first cook time to 30 minutes, turn off oven for 2 hours and check the temp. It was still delicious using this recipe for the first time. I also used The Spice House’s English Prime Rib Rub. I highly recommend

I highly recommend this method, it’s fool proof!
